Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I stood on the porch, package in hand, glancing at the familiar door. My stepdad’s name was on the label, and I knew he wouldn’t be home for hours. As a delivery person, I was supposed to leave the box safely, snap a photo, and move on. But as a step-child, I felt a tug of responsibility—Mom had sounded tired on the phone last night, and I’d promised myself I’d check in more often. I wanted to knock, maybe even call her, just to ask if everything was okay. But my route was tight, and lingering too long could get me in trouble at work. My boss expected efficiency, no exceptions. I stared at the door, torn between the urge to fulfill my family’s need for support and the pressure to do my job right. My heart pounded as I weighed the risks, feeling the two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
